edge: Newton is a government servant who is sent to a politically sensitive area of central India on election duty.

edge: Newton is sent to a politically sensitive area of central India on election duty.
The politically sensitive area of Central India where Newton is sent on election duty is located in Central India.
Newton had its world premiere in the Forum section of the 67th Berlin International Film Festival.
The world premiere of Newton was in the Forum section of the 67th Berlin International Film Festival.
Rajkummar Rao won the Best Actor (Critics) award for his role in Newton at the 63rd Filmfare Awards.
Newton won the National Film Award for Best Feature Film in Hindi.
Rajkummar Rao won the Asia Pacific Screen Award for Best Actor for his role in Newton.
Pankaj Tripathi won a special mention at the 65th National Film Awards for his performance in Newton.
Nutan 'Newton' Kumar was sent on election duty
Nutan 'Newton' Kumar was a reserve government clerk
Nutan 'Newton' Kumar was sent to a Naxal-controlled town in Chhattisgarh, India
The election duty was in a Naxal-controlled town
Nutan 'Newton' Kumar worked with Assistant Commandant Aatma Singh
Assistant Commandant Aatma Singh was a part of the Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF)
Assistant Commandant Aatma Singh was a part of the war-weary Central Reserve Police Force (CRPF)
Assistant Commandant Aatma Singh faced guerrilla attacks by communist insurgents
The villagers from the constituency were a part of the election duty
The foreign reporter arrived at the polling station
The CRPF force forced the villagers from the constituency to turn up for voting

The villagers have no idea what the election is about, some think they will earn money from it, others ask about getting paid sufficiently for their work. Newton tries to educate them but to no avail.
Pushes Newton aside and shames the villagers by telling them that these officers have risked their lives for their vote, and they should not turn them away.
Talks to the villagers and realizes that they have no idea what the election is about.

Aatma Singh tells the villagers that the voting machine is a toy and there are symbols of elephants, cycles, etc. They could press any symbol they like, leaving them uneducated about the fact that those symbols represent respective political parties.
The villagers vote for their favorite symbol instead of politicians they have never heard about, while the foreign reporter gets a good news report about India's democracy.

forced to flee due to Naxal ambush which Newton later realizes was actually staged by the CRPF, Newton tries to outrun his escort team back to the polling booth but gets caught on both sides and is forcibly taken back to safety
decides to collect the votes of four villagers who suddenly turn up from deep inside the forest, but Aatma Singh is reluctant to let them do so
steals Aatma Singh's rifle and holds the officer at gunpoint till the villagers cast their votes
wanted polling to be conducted in an area that was only secured by government forces 6 months ago, mentioning that there are still more landmines there than men
beats him up out of frustration
Malko visits Newton in his office and asks about the events that occurred after she left. Newton requests that she tells everything over tea, but only after five minutes when his lunch break begins.
The movie concludes with a shot of the area six months later, showing mining activity going on.

Conditions in Naxal-affected areas made Aatma Singh a dispassionate and cynical person. Aatma Singh is shown shopping in civilian dress with his wife and daughter during holidays, suggesting he is humane.
Newton is shown in his office wearing a neck brace for his injury from the beating but otherwise happy, and keeping with his old ways.
Rajeev Masand described Newton as 'relevant and timely' in his rating.
Rajeev Masand mentioned that Newton 'lays on its message too thick in the end' in his review.
The review by Rajeev Masand stated that Newton has a 'thrust' which creates an 'impact'.
Rajeev Masand did not mention boredom in his review of Newton.
Rajeev Masand did not mention inaccessibility in his review of Newton.
The review by Rajeev Masand stated that the 'pace' occasionally slips in Newton.
Neil Soans mentioned in his review that Newton is a comedy.
Neil Soans compared the audience's ignorance about an issue to 'blissful ignorance' in his review of Newton.
Neil Soans expressed that we should 'thank' the director for making Newton.
Rajeev Masand gave a rating of 4 stars out of 5 to Newton.
Neil Soans did not mention any rating for Newton in his review.

Newton is a dark comedy that gives you equal measures of dread and disillusionment and hope and hilarity. This is reality at its finest, with credible performances and backdrops that immerse viewers into the world.
Newton makes you see the pitfalls of the democratic system but also tells you that it's the only one capable of positive change.
Rajkummar Rao is enjoying a purple patch. After Bareilly Ki Barfi, here he is again stitching up a big performance full of small things: blinking, thinking, doing.
Pankaj Tripathi, as the head of the security detail, cynical yet doing the best he can, is lovely too.
For once the talented Patil has been used well, and as for Raghubir Yadav, he gives us, after Peepli Live, another stand-out act, a lesson in How To Immerse Yourself Effortlessly In Your Role.

Director Amit V Masurkar and co-scriptwriter Mayank Tewari have crafted a strong black comedy. It is as sharp and subversive as the classic Jaane Bhi Do Yaaro, and even though it is entirely sobering, it leaves us feeling just a little better about ourselves.

Newton is a dark comedy that gives you equal measures of dread and disillusionment and hope and hilarity. It makes you see the pitfalls of the democratic system but also tells you that it's the only one capable of positive change.

Shubhra Gupta of The Indian Express gave the film a rating of 4 stars out of 5 saying that, "Director Amit V Masurkar and co-scriptwriter Mayank Tewari have crafted a strong black comedy. It is as sharp and subversive as the classic Jaane Bhi Do Yaaro, and even though it is entirely sobering, it leaves us feeling just a little better about ourselves."

Shubhra Gupta of The Indian Express gave the film a rating of 4 stars out of 5 saying that, "Newton is a dark comedy that gives you equal measures of dread and disillusionment and hope and hilarity. This is reality at its finest, with credible performances and backdrops that immerse viewers into the world.""
Newton is a refreshing entry in the genre of commercial art house cinema.
Newton upholds the democratic process in a rebel-threatened area.
Newton is a touching, personal and very human film about the strength of one very resolute rookie election clerk to uphold the democratic process in a rebel-threatened area.
Harish Wankhede calls Newton 'A new Dalit Hero' in the Indian Express review.

Rohit Vats of Hindustan Times gave the film a rating of 4 stars out of 5 and said that, 'It is one of the finest political satires we have seen in the last couple of years. It refrains from taking sides and offers a humorous take on state versus the Maoists bloody battle. It raises questions on the importance of the electoral system we are so proud of. It takes us much beyond what we see.'

Harish Wankhede suggests that the most reviews of the film neglect the protagonist’s social identity, while emphasising the film’s creative aspects. 'A new Dalit hero is offered to the audience through the subtle use of certain symbolic gestures and social codes.'
Newton was India's official entry for the 90th Academy Awards.
Newton was India's official entry for the 90th Academy Awards; it was also the first Indian film to receive a grant of Rs 1 crore from the Central Government.
Newton had its world premiere at the Berlin International Film Festival held from 9–19 February 2017 in Berlin, Germany.
Newton got released on 22 September 2017.
Newton was a box office success.
After the film's release and its selection as India's entry for the Oscars, Newton was criticized for its striking similarities with the Iranian movie Secret Ballot.
Film-maker Anurag Kashyap voiced his support to the team of Newton, stating "Newton is as much a copy of Secret Ballot, The Avengers is of Watan Ke Rakhwale".
